item.title: Local testing Kubernetes cluster with Kind
item.description: Should you not already have a nice cluster to test on, you can spin up a local Kubernetes cluster using Kind. Kind uses Docker containers to represent nodes. Unlike minikube, this one boots up in less than a minute and can easily be extended with additional pretend nodes, making it superior for working with distributed applications. item.title: Truncating a Kafka topic
item.description: Sometimes, you want to get rid of messages from a Kafka topic. Perhaps you have consumers that always start from the beginning, or you realize the whole topic is full of messages with sensitive data that must not reach consumers. In theory, you can easily delete a Kafka topic. However, this is quite disruptive and is likely to fail both producers and consumers on this topic even if you quickly recreate the topic.
